div1.p: Carter reports that she and Brown remain hard at work writing to individuals who may be able to help them track down a few elusive references.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to Frederick F. Russell, October 12, 1928
div1.opener:
Book, Misel
Report (weekly)-!
The Westmoreland,
2122 California St., N. W.
Washington, D. C.
October 12, 1928.
Dear Doctor Russell:
div1.p:
I have the honor to report another week of intensive, and very satis-
factory work, both in tracing elusive references and in cooperation with Dr.
Frost. I sent him a lot of material yesterday and Miss Brown and I are in hopes of
getting another lot ready for him to-night.

One of the most onerous parts of the present work is writing letters to
individuals who may be able to throw some light on the remaining unverified ref-
erences. Everyone to whom I have written from whom I have heard at all, has been most kind, and some of them,
notably[unclear] Mr. Van Wesep, Connor and LePrince, very helpful as well. In this con-
nection, I have just received a letter from Mr. Van Wesep giving me some ex-
tracts from Goeldi, for which I shall thank him personally as soon as I have time.

Miss Brown is indegfatigable in her efforts,, and most efficient. Indeed, I cannot too highly
praise her work. A letter, just received from Dr. Frost, has made me feel very
happy about my own output as well. I'd hate to confess to Dr. Thayer the amount of
time I'm putting in on the work; however, we're near enough the end for that fact
to “justify the means!”

This is being written at the Library of Congress, just before closing time, on
my portable typewriter, which is much the worse for the number of library cards
it has had to type, hence the uneven appearance of this letter.
div1.closer:
With best wishes, I remain
Very truly yours, Laura A. Carter Dr. Frederick F. Russell, Director,
International Health Division
The Rockefeller Foundation,
61 Broadway, New York, N. Y.
